key_title: Key to the genera of Chenopodiaceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Chenopodiaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Walsh, N.G. (1996). Chenopodiaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Plant apparently leafless or leaves reduced to opposite, fleshy lobes at regular intervals along fleshy, jointed stems
Plant obviously leafy; leaves opposite or alternate; stems not jointed and fleshy
Leaves with flat blades, usually petiolate; fruit not developing prominent spines; plant often mealy-pubescent or glandular
Leaves narrow, often terete or subterete, usually apparently sessile; fruit sometimes developing spines; plant neither mealy-pubescent nor glandular
Plant glabrous; ovary semi-inferior; fruiting perianths woody or corky toward base, adhering together by the swollen receptacle
Plant usually mealy, at least when young; ovary superior; fruiting perianths sometimes clustered but not adhering together
[link through]

Flowers always unisexual; males with 5-lobed perianth and 5 stamens; females lacking perianth but enclosed by a pair of free to almost entirely fused bracteoles which enlarge in fruit, often becoming spongy, corky and/or with dorsal outgrowths
Flowers bisexual or unisexual; all with a perianth and never enclosed by paired bracteoles
Fruit a succulent berry
Fruit dry
Plants shrubby; flowers unisexual; the male flowers with 5 stamens
Plant wiry and spreading or ascending and softly woody; flowers bisexual or female; bisexual flowers with 1–5 stamens
Flowers with 5 stamens; fruiting perianth enlarged, yellow to dark reddish on inner face
Flowers with 1–3 stamens; fruiting perianth not enlarged or coloured (the pericarp may be brightly coloured)
Herb with basal rosette of leaves; tepals 4, enlarged and hard in fruit, strongly arched near base and exposing the fruit
Plant without a basal rosette, or if leaves apparently rosetted then fruiting perianth not as above
[link through]
Fruiting perianth with a prominent membranous wing; flowering branches wiry, widely spreading; uncommon pasture weed of north-west
Fruiting perianth unwinged
[link through]
Plants aromatic, with glandular hairs
Plants eglandular
Tepals 3–5; seed horizontal to vertical; annuals or soft-wooded shrubby perennials
Tepals 5; seed horizontal; perennial herbs or slender, wiry subshrubs
Flowers and fruits fused in axillary clusters of 2 or more
Flowers and fruits solitary in axils, or if ever paired or clustered then remaining free
Fruiting perianth succulent, berry-like, yellow to red, totally enclosing fruit, slit down one side
Fruiting perianth dry, or if succulent, thinly so and remaining green, not slit down the side
[link through]
Fruiting perianth winged or with prominent spines, ridges or tubercles
Fruiting perianth lacking wings, spines or prominent tubercles
Fruit woody; flowers not subtended by bracteoles
Fruit not woody; flowers subtended by a pair of bracteoles
Flowering perianth 5-lobed; fruiting perianth dry, subglobular; inland
Flowering perianth 3-lobed; fruiting perianth thinly succulent, ovoid to urceolate; coasts and inland
[link through]
Fruiting perianth winged (narrowly so in Sclerochlamys)
Fruiting perianth unwinged, but with spines, cylindrical lobes, or tubercles
Leaves spine-tipped; each flower subtended by a pair of conspicuous, leaf-like bracteoles; annual
Leaves not spine-tipped; flowers ebracteolate or with minute scale-like bracteoles; annuals or perennials
[link through]
Annual; tepals of fruiting perianth with horizontal wings and a short, hooked spine attached near the middle; uncommon weed of north-west
Perennials; fruiting perianth lacking spines
[link through]
Fruiting perianth lenticular to turbinate or globose, not obviously pentagonal at summit, with 5 horizontal wings or these fused forming a single annular ring
Fruiting perianth hemispherical, truncate and pentagonal at summit with the perimeter narrowly winged
[link through]
Fruiting perianth with 2 series of 5 appendages, the upper deeply divided, the lower entire or narrowly lobed and spinose
Fruiting perianth with appendages in a single series
[link through]
Fruiting perianth hard, cup-shaped to subglobular with c. 11 short spines radiating from the truncate apex
Fruiting perianth with 1–6 spines or blunt lobes
Fruiting perianth Y-shaped, with 3 soft, woolly lobes
Fruiting perianth tubular to subglobose, with 1–6 hard spines
[link through]
Fruiting perianth cylindrical, spongy, shortly 5-spined, the spines united into a cup-like structure
Fruiting perianth shape various, woody, with 1–6 spines arising between perianth lobes
[link through]
Flowers in cymules of 3; perianth lacking an upper lobe; stamen 1
Flowers in cymules of 5–13 (or false whorls of 10–26) between bracts of inflorescence; perianth with an upper lobe overlapping the 2 lateral lobes; stamens 2
